body:
To help debug BLE issues, please:

1. Install the [dev build of ble-main](https://github.com/oliexdev/openScale/releases/tag/travis-dev_ble-main-build).
2. Create an user if one doesn't exists.
3. Go to Settings -> About and enable debug log.
4. Go to Settings -> Bluetooth and scan for your scale. Once found, click on it. Wait for openScale to fetch extended info from the scale. If it takes more than 30 seconds you can abort it. 
5. Go back to the main screen and click the Bluetooth button and try to fetch measurements from the scale.

Then report your result as a comment here. Remember to attach (i.e. don't copy paste it as a comment) the debug log. Also describe what you did and what happened.

title: New View with Moving Average
label: [Label(name="question")]
body:
When you measure daily your weight, you will see a volatile curve, with +- 2kg without changing your diet. 
Reason is simple: water, Food, etc. 

To eliminate this, there is an approach to weigh your measures over the last 10 measures. so called moving average. 

So, I don't know how complex this is to program, but it would be a great added value to have this option in openScale. 

More details and example: 
1. https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=net.cachapa.libra (an app which does this, but is not supported anymore)
2. The guy who invented this approach: https://www.fourmilab.ch/hackdiet/e4/
3. A web solution which use the moving average: https://trendweight.com/

title: Support for Senssun Fat scales
label: [Label(name="scale support")]
body:
Hi.

Scales are sold here in AU at Kmart, the original app worked beautifully just one time.
Stores up to 12 users, has internal storage for some information.

Found some code that covers my scales perfectly

https://github.com/zhangjing02/MySenssunSdk/blob/master/sdk/src/main/java/cn/senssun/ble/sdk/fat/BleConnectService.java#L178

pretty much has everything you need! I haven't tested any of the user storage functionality (it's way past bed time and sending commands with _nRF Connect_ is very manual, usually resulting in the scales turning off before I can send) but everything in there seems to work with regards to measurements.

Can confirm my device service is `0000fff0-0000-1000-8000-00805f9b34fb`

Can confirm notifications from `0000fff1-0000-1000-8000-00805f9b34fb` of 8 bytes

**Standard operation**
`FF A5 02 03 04 05 06 07`

`FF` is discarded
`A5` is measurement
`06` Is type

If `06` is `AA` or `A0` then the measurement is weight in KG and lb, `AA` means stable measurement, `A0` unstable measurement.
`02 03` is weight in  100 gram increments (611 is 61.1kg)
`04 05` is weight in lb

**After triggering a fat test**

If `06` is `B0` then the measurement is Fat and Hydration, if it's BE then there was an error

`02 03` is fat in 0.1% increments (218 is 21.8%)
`04 05` is hydration in 0.1% increments (53.5 is 53.5%)

If `06` is `C0` then the measurement is Muscle and Bone

`02 03` is muscle in 0.1% increments (543 is 54.3%)
`05 04` is bone in 0.1% increments (39 is 3.9%) - *nb this is backwards*

If `06` is `D0` then the measurement is calculated calories

`02 03` app lists as amr kcal

If `06` is `E0`, `E1`, `E2`, or `F0` then its related to stored data sets


Send command to `0000fff2-0000-1000-8000-00805f9b34fb`

`A5 30 00 00 00 00 00 00 00` - Set date https://github.com/zhangjing02/MySenssunSdk/blob/master/sdk/src/main/java/cn/senssun/ble/sdk/fat/BleConnectService.java#L587
`A5 31 00 00 00 00 00 00 00` - Set time https://github.com/zhangjing02/MySenssunSdk/blob/master/sdk/src/main/java/cn/senssun/ble/sdk/fat/BleConnectService.java#L610


`A5 10 01 24 B4 00 00 D2 00` - Triggers a fat test

`A5 10` are preamble
`01` is 0+1 (0 for man - 128 for woman, 1 is my 'user')
`24` is age
`B4` is height in cm

Some log: [log-2018-07-27.txt](https://github.com/oliexdev/openScale/files/2232408/log-2018-07-27.txt)

title: Add a ContentProvider so other apps can access (with permission) the …
body:
…openScale data.

This could be used for e.g. syncing weight logs to a third-party service such as Google Fit,
without the openScale app having to do so; with this, a 'connector' app could be written that
reads this data and does the push to a third-party service (or, indeed, an HTTP RPC connector,
an MQTT connector, SMS notifications, or anything else) without openScale needing this
functionality (or additional permissions).

This is a straw-man implementation; happy to discuss how you think this should work, if this is a dumb idea altogether and I should abandon it, etc. Really a proof-of-concept as much as anything else. This is, though, basically the approach suggested by oliexdev at https://github.com/oliexdev/openScale/issues/82 - "Another solution is to write for e.g. lets call it "openScale Connector" app which listen and access the internal sql database of openScale and send any new data via MQTT or to any company clouds (GARMIN,Google Fit and so on)", and I think a ContentProvider is the most "Androidy" way to do this (and allows locking down this sensitive data behind permissions to prevent malicious apps doing so without user knowledge).

Here's how the flow looks from a dummy third-party app I hacked together which just dumps the data as text:

title: Support for the official BLE standard
label: [Label(name="question")]
body:
Hi!

In the course of my master thesis I am developing a BLE simulator. We simulate the Bluetooth Low Energy standard and cross-test various mobile health applications to check for their compliance with the BLE standard.

I am pretty sure the simulator is mimicking a default BLE scale as defined per the BLE standardization (https://www.bluetooth.com/specifications/gatt/viewer?attributeXmlFile=org.bluetooth.service.weight_scale.xml) but still, the openScale application reports it to be not supported.

My question now is: Is this a not yet implemented device, or is my simulator not working properly?
All my tests and cross-checks seem to indicate that the standard is sufficiently simulated, though.

Bests

Fabian

title: Incorrect display/calculation of goal weight and weight difference in statistics screen v1.8.1
label: [Label(name="bug")]
body:
In version 1.8.x (1.8 and 1.8.1), the goal weight and weight difference are not displayed correctly in the Statistics tab. The first problem is that when using the Imperial system units (lbs, in), regardless of what is entered for user's starting weight and goal weight, the goal weight does not match what is entered in the user profile. This happens regardless of other user profile information (gender, height, etc.). See example below:

Data from user profile:
Initial weight: 200.0 lb
Goal weight: 175.0 lb

Data displayed in statistics tab (no additional measurements)
Goal weight: 79.4 lb
Weight difference: 79.4 lb

Data displayed in statistics tab (measurement at 198 lb added)
Goal weight: 79.4 lb
Weight difference: 118.6 lb

It correctly calculates goal weight but does so with the incorrect goal weight. After putting in a couple different values for goal weights, it looks like what may be happening is that the values may be getting converted to SI units (kg) while still retaining the English label (lbs), i.e. 175.0 lb = 79.4 kg.

The second (minor) issue is that regardless of which unit system is used, the weight difference is not correctly calculated when there are not any measurements entered, i.e. immediately after the user is created but before the first set of measurements is entered. In other words, the app currently displays **weight difference = goal weight** (see above), but instead it should be calculated it as **weight difference = initial weight (from user profile) - goal weight**. Then when a users has entered their first weight value in the app, the formula would change to **weight difference = most recent measured weight - goal weight**.

Also, as an aside, thank you for all the work you are doing on this app - it is a great resource and a very helpful contribution to the open source ecosystem on Android! :) keep up the great work!

title: Carry over additional measurements not present in all records
label: [Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
# Use Case:
As a user I would like to be able to realize the following use case:
- Daily use of one of the supported BTLE scales using them to measure whatever they provide. (Schedule A)
- Weekly or less than daily measurement of other manual metrics such as e.g. waist size (Schedule B) 
- I would like to have the current measurement of schedule B to be carried over / applied to measurements of Schedule A until the next measurement of schedule B is available.
- Thus, all records would have data for automatic and manual measurements present. 

# Rationale / Current state
- Currently I have to generate a new measurement that gets the latest automatic / schedule A measurements and add my manual measurements.
- Upon looking at the diagrams this leads to wrong / weird display of data as it appears that the 0 entries for the additional / manual measurements on schedule A records are included in the diagramming / calculation process leading to wrong / undesirable results.

title: Database upgrade and cleanup
body:
Changes the constraint for datetime to also include userId so that two users can have measurement for the same time. Also added a foreign key constraint so that there must be an user to be able to add a measurement. Added migration + test to verify that the upgrade works.

Tested import of a backup database with version 1. To have the migration steps run after import I changed the code to reopen the database after the import is done.

Also introduced caching of the selected scale user so that it doesn't have to be read from the database all the time.

Also some cleanups, such as the removal of unused methods from the old database classes.

title: Refactor measurement views
body:
The biggest part of this PR involves refactoring the inheritance hierarchy for MeasurementViews by adding a new FloatMeasurementView that all measurement views that holds a float inherits from. This way the base class MeasurementView can be cleaned up as much code is moved to FloatMeasurementView where it can deal with the value in a more explicit way as it is always float there.

The second part of this involves changing the DataEntryActivity to not save measurements to the database when navigating between them unless they have been modified. This improves the performance when switching between measurements. I have some more things I would like to do in this area, such as changing how the active user is handled, but that is for later.

DataEntryActivity now holds on to a clone of the ScaleMeasurement it is displaying, which makes it easier to update when something changes and cascade the changes to the other views.

Other performance improvements includes not updating the views unless the value has changed and using SpannableStringBuilder instead of Html.fromHtml to style text (only in MeasurementView, not yet in TableFragment).

title: "Normal" weight vs "Normal" bmi
label: [Label(name="question")]
body:
I understand that in EvaluationSheet.java one defines the values of "normal" parameters. For BMI one uses age and sex instead of the simplified version which considers normal everything between 18.5 and 24.99.
For weight, however, one just assumes that normal BMI is between 20 and 25 (for men) and from it and the heigth it derives the normal weight.  For ages>40 or ages<20 this leads to inconsistencies (one could be overweight according to weight and underweight according to BMI). The assumed variation of "normal" BMI with age is probably  too agressive. Probably one should set the correct BMI limits first and from them derive the correct weight limits.

title: Reverse engineering Yunmai mini scale
label: [Label(name="help wanted"), Label(name="scale support")]
body:
I am trying to reverse engineer the yunmai mini scale.

I already found out the weight values but I can't figure out the body fat percentage, muscle percentage and so on. Any help or idea is welcome.

So far what I got:

- No weight values are stored on the scale itself. You have to be connected to the yunmai app to receive any data
- Weights are continuous send to UUID: Unknown (0xffe4) (if you stay on the scale)
- Sent values are like `0d:1f:0b:01:59:c6:15:2f:26:95:03`
  * byte 0-6: bytes are constant
  * byte 7: first nibble is constant, second nibble is changing
  * byte 8-9: contains the weight value (here `0x2695` = 9877 = 98,77 btw the value is rounded in the yunmai app as 98,8 kg)
  * byte 10: is changing
- last measurement from the scale of the continuous sent send data looks like `0d:1f:14:02:00:59:c6:15:2f:23:d0:b6:32:26:95:00:a5:08:f2:37`
  * byte 0-5: bytes are constant
  * byte 6: first nibble is constant, second nibble is changing
  * byte 7-8: bytes are changing
  * byte 9-12: bytes are constant
  * byte 13-14: contains the weight value again
  * byte 15: bytes are constant
  * byte 16-19: bytes are changing
- after that the yunmai app send some values to the scale. In response they send some values back to the scale like the following `0d:1f:12:06:01:23:d0:b6:32:af:01:19:55:5a:8d:26:01:6f`
-  I guess that the values displayed in the yunmai app are rounded values like as the weight value
- Since so many bytes are constant and only few bytes are changing it could be possible that the information of the body measurements (like fat, muscle, water percentage etc.) are compressed or somehow encrypted. (for example a fat percentage of 22,9 % is somehow in the above values encoded)

title: MiScale initial sync: Better way to assign values to users?
label: [Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="question")]
body:
While testing version 1.5.2 I stumbled upon an annoying problem:

If you use your scale with more than one person you have to set additional openScale user(s) to use the smart assignment for filtering away unwanted measurements.

But when you initially sync your MiScale, ALL stored values are synced to the currently active openScale user and you have to manually delete A LOT OF measurements after that. I tried it with two users but I don't know what do do if there are more family members using the scale.

Is there another (less time-consuming) way to assign the values to the users? Our scale is almost two months in use and I had to delete virtually hundreds of values. What happens if one installs openscale and there are thousands of values stored on the family scale? ... 
There must be a better way to achieve this separation... (multiple cut paste for example, or selecting and moving all values in a specified weight range).

The current behavior works but it can be extremely exhausting for new openScale users to sync their scale if their family used the MiScale for months/years before.

I think MiFit simply ignores all old values when you register a new user and asks you to step on the scale to 'connect' your user to the right weight range. In fact the users of MiFit even don't know that their scale provides a history of old values. I think most of them would be satisfied if openScale behaves like MiFit in this point - at least as the default.

edit
Idea: When a user tries to sync his MiScale to an 'empty openScale user", openScale could ask him to step on the scale and after that press ok. Then openScale could do the sync and discard all but the last value. In future syncs only fitting measurements younger than the initial sync could be added to this openScale user. This would mimic the MiFit behavior.

title: Inappropriate scale for charts
label: [Label(name="question")]
body:
First of all, thanks for the app!

I'd like to mention that the scale you use while building charts (starting from 0) isn't the best solution. This results in almost straight line, especially on small screen of a smartphone. This makes the chart completely useless. No one will weight 0 or 10 or 20 (even 60 for me personally) kilos. And there's no need to use this values while building charts. The better way is to take upper and lower results, add some margin (say, 2-5 kg) and use the resulting scale. Or use target weight as lower bound.

Also, in a year chart there's no need to reserve the scale up to end of the year. Doing so in January we will get almost blank screen. X-line should have 1st of January as 0 and the current date (plus some margin, say, one week) as its right bound.

And the last, putting all the values on a chart isn't a good idea when you have many records. Better not to put at all (or have a setting to put or not) or put only for peak values.

Look what I have in openScale and other similar program with exactly the same data:
